abbreviations.et seq: (et sequentes) and those (pages or section) that follow

affadavit.definition: A voluntary declaration of facts written down and sworn to by the declarant before an officer authorized to administer oaths.
affadavit.usage: A great deal of evidence is submitted by affidavit, esp. in pretrial matters such as summary-judgment motions

citation.definition:
1. A court-issued writ that commands 
a person to appear at a certain time and place to do 
something demanded in the writ, or to show cause for 
not doing so. 2. A police-issued order to appear before a 
judge on a given date to defend against a stated charge, 
such as a traffic violation. 
Also termed appearance 
ticket. [Cases: Automobiles (;:::>351.1.] 3. A reference to 
a legal precedent or authority, such as a case, statute, or 
treatise, that either substantiates or contradicts a given 
position. 
Often shortened to (in sense 3) cite

common law.definition:
1. The body of law derived from judicial 
decisions, rather than from statutes or constitutions;

contempt.definition:
1. The act or state of despising; the 
condition ofbeing despised. 2. Conduct that defies the 
authority or dignity ofa court or legislature.
contempt.usage:
Because 
such conduct interferes with the administration of 
justice, it is punishable, usu. by fine or imprisonment. 
Fed. R. Civ. P. 45(e); Fed. R. Crim. P. 42; 18 USCA § 40l.

continuance.definition:
1. The act ofkeeping up, maintain­
ing, or prolonging <continuance of the formal tradi­
tion>. 2. Duration; time of continuing <the senator's 
continuance in office>. 3. Procedure. The adjournment 
or postponement of a trial or other proceeding to a 
future date <motion for continuance>.

execute.definition:
1. To perform or complete (a contract 
or duty) Cases: Contracts 
2. To change (as a 
legal interest) from one form to another . 3. To make 
(a legal document) valid by signing; to bring (a legal 
document) into its final, legally enforceable form 
<each party executed the contract without a signa­
ture witness>. 4. To put to death, esp. by legal sentence 
[Cases: 
Sentencing and Punishment
 5. To enforce 
and collect on (a money judgment)
execute.usage:
<once the contract was fully executed, the 
parties owed no further contractual duties to each 
other>. 

<the shifting 
use was executed into a valid legal estate>

<Johnson was executed shortly after midnight>. 

<Williams asked th sheriff to execute on the judgment>

executed.definition:
1. (Of a document) that has been 
signed <an executed will>. 2. That has been done, given, 
or performed <executed consideration>. 
"[Tlhe term 'executed' is a slippery word. Its use is to be 
avoided except when accompanied by explanation.... 
A contract is frequently said to be executed when the 
document has been signed, or has been signed, sealed, 
and delivered. Further, by executed contract is frequently 
meant one that has been fully performed by both parties." 
William R. Anson, Principles of the Law of Contract 26 n.* 
(Arthur l. Corbin ed., 3d Am. ed. 1919

oath.definition:
1. A solemn declaration, accompanied 
by a swearing to God or a revered person or thing, 
that one's statement is true or that one will be bound 
to a promise. 
2. A statement or promise made by such a declaration. 
3. A form of words used for such a declaration. 4. A 
formal declaration made solemn without a swearing 
to God or a revered person or thing; AFFIRMATION. Cf. 
PLEDGE (1).
oath.usage:
The person making the oath implic­
itly invites punishment if the statement is untrue or 
the promise is broken. The legal effect of an oath is to 
subject the person to penalties for perjury if the testi­
mony is false.

oath of office.definition:
An oath taken by a person about 
to enter into the duties of public office, by which the 
person promises to perform the duties of that office 
in good faith

officer.definition: A person who holds an office of trust, authority, or command
officer.usage: In public affairs, the term refers esp to a person holding public office under a nation, state, or local government, and authorized by that government to excercise some specific fucntion. In coporate law, the term refers esp to a person elected daily operation of a corporation, such as a CEO, president, secretary, or tresurer.
